wherein it is placed next to <u>Lunulites</u>, which undoubtedly belongs
to the group of Bryozoa (Polyzoa) as now restricted. This Family
he characterises as follows:-"Gemmis in eodem plano prodeuntibus,
polyparia plana, discoidea<s>,</s> formantibus, osculis distinctis
post mortem apertis;" and it is by the last of these characters,
that he distinguishes it from the family <u>Soritidae</u>, consisting of
the two genera <u>Sorites</u> and <u>Amphisorus</u>, of which he says:-
"osculis contracto corpore, tanquam operculo duro clausis." If
any faith whatever is to be placed in Prof.  Ehrenberg's figures
and descriptions, his <u>Sorites</u> is nothing else than Lamarck's
<u>Orbulites marginalis</u>, whilst his <u>Amphisorus</u>, which differs
from Sorites merely in having two layers of cells instead of one,
is (as I shall hereafter show) is the same type in a higher grade
of development. I cannot conceal mu astonishment, however,
that so practised a microscopic observer should have entirely
overlooked the real marginal openings between the cells; still
more, that he should have described the entirely-closed cells of the
surface as covered in by a moveable operculum, which merely shuts
their orifices when the animal is contracted; and further, that,
